title: 107_hr1217
content:
The Act titled "Multilingual Education and Technological Advancement Act of 2001" provides grants for computer software for multilingual education. The "Multilingual Education and Technological Advancement Act of 2001" authorizes the Secretary of Education to award grants to local educational agencies for computer software for multilingual education. Preference is given to schools with students from low-income families or with low English proficiency levels. Grants can be used for elementary and secondary schools. The grant program under the "Multilingual Education and Technological Advancement Act of 2001" is for elementary or secondary schools meeting specific criteria. The Secretary conducts an annual study on the program's effectiveness and submits a report to Congress with findings and recommendations. To apply for a grant, a local educational agency must follow the application process. To seek a grant under the "Multilingual Education and Technological Advancement Act of 2001," a local educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary containing required information. $80,000,000 is authorized for grants for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. Grants for computers are available under the "Multilingual Education and Technological Advancement Act of 2001." The Secretary of Education may award grants to local educational agencies for elementary and secondary schools to obtain computers. Grants are mandatory for schools serving a majority of students from low-income families. Eligible schools can use the grant for financial assistance. The Secretary of Education provides grants to local educational agencies for elementary and secondary schools with low-income students or insufficient computers. Schools must apply for the grant following the Secretary's requirements. The Secretary is allocated $100,000,000 annually for grants under this section from 2002 to 2006. SEC. 4. INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY TRAINING AND MULTILINGUAL EDUCATION PROGRAM GRANTS. The Secretaries may make grants to eligible partnerships for information technology training programs for various groups and multilingual education programs. Eligible partnerships consist of an institution of higher education and a private organization. To seek a grant, an eligible partnership must submit an application. To apply for a grant under this program, eligible partnerships must submit an application to the Secretaries. The Federal share of the cost is 50 percent, while the non-Federal share can be provided in cash, in kind, or through services. $100,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding for subsequent years. Bonus grants are available for information technology certification under Section 5. The Secretary of Education may grant funds to local educational agencies to award bonuses to teachers who achieve information technology certification, with a limit of $5,000 per teacher. Agencies must submit an application with the required information to be eligible for the grant. The local educational agency can receive funds to award bonuses to teachers who achieve information technology certification, with a limit of $5,000 per teacher. The agency must report the number of teachers with IT certification and those who have not received a bonus before. $120,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. SEC. 6. SCHOLARSHIPS FOR TEACHER TRAINING.

Grants may be awarded to institutions of higher education to provide scholarships to eligible students preparing to enter the teaching workforce. Eligible students must meet criteria requiring technological and multilingual education. $100,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002 and subsequent years.

SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, a "certified commercial information technology training provider" is defined as a private sector provider certified by software publishers or hardware manufacturers for training in information technology. A "dislocated worker" is defined as per the Workforce Investment Act of 1998. The term "elementary school" is defined as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. "Information technology certification" refers to certification in information technology, issued by relevant industry associations or state boards after consultation with education authorities. The term "information technology training program" refers to a program for training computer programmers, systems analysts, computer scientists, engineers, and other occupations as determined appropriate by the Secretaries after consultation with relevant entities and associations. The term "institution of higher education" refers to an entity defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "local educational agency" refers to an entity defined in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "Native American" means an Indian or Native Hawaiian as defined in the Workforce Investment Act of 1998. The term "secondary school" refers to an entity defined in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "veteran" is defined in section 101 of the Workforce Investment Act of 1998. The term "Secretaries" refers to the Secretary of Education and the Secretary of Labor acting jointly.
